I just wanted to, I guess, talk from the context of – they are very short-lived three months or so to the cut over at the front end. Just at the back end, I had the time lines moved and what are the time lines for closing down some of the larger Legacy billing and CRM systems. And also whether you can reaffirm, I am not sure if it is in the pack, the targets you had for network and systems reduction by FY '10, if you are still on track with those?

Yeah, the plan that we've had all along, and we said all along is second half of '09 fiscal year and the '10 year is kind of the big year is when we start retiring systems and '11 and '12, those will be the years; that hasn't changed. The issue in every migration, if any of you have ever been involved with the migration, and you've seen companies that do well, which are very few and companies that don't do it well which are a lot, is that you've got to get the code right. And that's where we are at. I am sitting here today very happy about where we're at, and yes, we might be off a month or two, but in terms of our core numbers, EBITDA margins which is reflective of OpEx and our free cash, which is reflective of capital and other issues there, we're not changing anything.
And just the systems and network cluster types '10, those original numbers given by far, you are still standing by that.

I mean they are going to be close whether we are off by 5 or 10 or 20 here or there, I don't know whether that's going to be the case, because as you remember we've – some of us were brand new to the company. And in October, we did an inventory with people that had been here 20 or 30 years in Telstra. We identified that we had 1,250 systems. And as we got into it about six, nine, twelve months later, we found out we had 1,500 systems. So, there is a lot of complexity to this and so the variability of plus or minus 10 or 20, that could be part of the story. But the punch line is the essence of the delivery, the essence of the margins, the essence of the free cash flow, which is what a shareholder cares about, those will be hit.
Thank you.
Okay.

Sol, Tim Smeallie, Citi. Obviously, the FOXTEL distributions this year are nice earnings kicker. I guess the status changed around those distributions about three times from November last year. I guess could you give us some color in terms of why that was suspended, and then also, what would be the catalyst to see those capital distributions reinstated?

Well, let me start first, Tim, with the whole notion of FOXTEL. And I've had this conversation with John, and I've had the conversation with our whole team here. FOXTEL is part of our Company. It's part of our ongoing business. And everybody in this room should understand that, so that when we think about FOXTEL now, we should think about it as a revenue stream, a cash stream, a part of our Company that we also took the hits on for a number of years in terms of the CapEx and the negative cash flows that occurred for several years. So, part of a – as a policy, we, the News Corp folks and the Packer folks – I'll just shorthand it – we've all agreed on a distribution dividend cash distribution policy, and that will be implemented. During the past year, there was a time, let's say, effect given what the financial markets are in terms of how we go about leveraging the balance sheet of that business to enable the payout. And we're going to not do stupid things just because we want to get something on a certain date. And I think John and his team along with the other members or partners we have, we are very mindful of that. John, do you want to add to that?
No, you've covered it well. I mean it's about, there's nothing changed in FOXTEL's policy, and it's just about timing given the financial markets.

So, can we assume then that if we saw a reduction in rates in the Aussie market and it was more attractive to take on the funding, because it wasn't aggressive, it was only three times what net debt to EBITDA for the business. The business is delivering right numbers we've seen today, it's on a great trajectory, I guess, does a reduction in rates provide scope that that type of a distribution program will be put back in place.
That's what I said in a different way.
Okay. That's correct. Thank you.
Thanks, any questions in the Melbourne? Looks like no questions in Melbourne.
Well, I don't see anybody else lined up here. So I want to thank all of you for coming today and we'll see you next time. Thank you.
